translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Well-Spoken
Thus have I heard:

original: eka samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.
There the Buddha addressed the monks:
“Monks!”
“Venerable sir,” they replied.
The Buddha said this:

original: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā subhāsitā hoti, na dubbhāsitā, anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca viññūnaṁ.
analyzed: catūhi bhikkhave aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā su bhāsitā hoti na dubbhāsitā anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca
translated: “Monks, speech that has four qualities is well-spoken, not badly spoken, and is blameless and beyond reproach by the wise.
What four?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu subhāsitaṁyeva bhāsati no dubbhāsitaṁ, dhammaṁyeva bhāsati no adhammaṁ, piyaṁyeva bhāsati no appiyaṁ, saccaṁyeva bhāsati no alikaṁ.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu su bhāsitayā iva bhāsati no dubbhāsita dhammayā iva bhāsati no adhamma piyayā iva bhāsati no appiya saccayā iva bhāsati no alika
translated: Here, a monk speaks only what is well-spoken, not what is badly spoken; he speaks only the Teaching, not what is contrary to the Teaching; he speaks what is pleasing, not what is unpleasing; he speaks truthfully, not falsely.

original: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā subhāsitā hoti, no dubbhāsitā, anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca viññūnan”ti.
analyzed: imehi kho bhikkhave catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā su bhāsitā hoti no dubbhāsitā anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca viññūnanti
translated: Speech that has these four qualities is well-spoken, not badly spoken, and is blameless and beyond reproach by the wise.”
This is what the Buddha said.

original: Idaṁ vatvāna sugato, athāparaṁ etadavoca satthā:
analyzed: idam vatvāna sugataḥ atha aparam etat avoca satthā
translated: Having said this, the Happy One, the Teacher, further said this:

original: “Subhāsitaṁ uttamamāhu santo,🔽Dhammaṁ bhaṇe nādhammaṁ taṁ dutiyaṁ;
analyzed: su bhāsitam uttamam āhu santaḥ  dhammam bhaṇe na adhammam tam dutiya
translated: “The good say that speaking well is supreme,🔽Speaking Dhamma, not what is not Dhamma, is second,

analyzed: piyam bhaṇe na appiyam tam tatiya
translated: Speaking what is dear, not what is not dear, is third,

analyzed: saccam bhaṇe nālikam tam catuttham ti
translated: Speaking truth, not what is false, is fourth.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai vaṅgīsaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā ekasam cīvaram katvā yena bhagavā tena añjalim paṇāmetvā bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then venerable Vaṅgīsa, having risen from his seat, after arranging his robe on one shoulder, extending his hands in reverential salutation towards the Fortunate One, said this to the Fortunate One:

analyzed: paṭibhāti ma bhagavā paṭibhāti ma sugata ati
translated: “It is clear to me, Fortunate One, it is clear to me, Happy One.”
“It is clear to you, Vaṅgīsa,” said the Fortunate One.

original: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso bhagavantaṁ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīsaḥ bhagavantam sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi
translated: Then venerable Vaṅgīsa, after praising the Fortunate One with appropriate verses in his presence, said this to the Fortunate One:

analyzed: tam eva vācam bhāseyya  yāyattānam na tāpaye
translated: “One should speak just such speech🔽As does not torment oneself,
And does not torment another,

analyzed: sā ve vācā su bhāsitā  piya vācam eva bhāseyya
translated: That is indeed the right kind of speech.🔽One should speak just such speech
As is agreeable to the ear,
Which is loved and desired,
Which is pleasing to the many people.
Truth is indeed the deathless speech,
This is the eternal Dhamma,
“The good say that truth, meaning, and Dhamma
are well-established.
The speech that the Buddha speaks
is safe, leading to Nibbāna,
to the end of suffering.
That is the best of all speech.”🔽The third sub-chapter on good speech is finished.
